title: Capturing electronic patient reported outcomes in oncology practice. - ASCO Publications

summary.text: The study highlights the importance of capturing electronic patient reported outcomes (ePRO) in oncology practice to enhance patient-centered care and improve treatment decisions.
Implementing ePRO systems can lead to better monitoring of patients' symptoms and quality of life during cancer treatment, allowing for timely interventions and adjustments to therapy.
Integration of ePRO into standard clinical workflows requires robust data management and analysis capabilities to ensure that the insights gained are actionable and directly inform patient care.

title: Patient-Reported Outcomes in Older Adults With Transthyretin Amyloid Cardiomyopathy - JACC

summary.text: PROs can provide a more holistic evaluation of how treatments impact patients as individuals, helping improve shared decision-making, treatment escalation, and assessment of treatment response in older adults with transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM).

The Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire (MLHFQ) and Euro-Qol 5 dimension-5 levels (EQ-5D-5 L) were predictors of all-cause mortality independent of biomarkers in ATTR-CM, demonstrating the importance of PROs alongside traditional clinical outcomes.

Despite challenges posed by increasingly "less sick" populations in ATTR-CM trials and a shift towards favorable FDA approval based on PRO and HR-QoL, CV outcome trials will remain costly. Favoring composite endpoints or win ratio approaches that include functional endpoints like 6-minute walk distance and patient-reported outcome measures can provide valuable insights into disease progression and treatment effects in ATTR-CM.

title: Patient-Reported Outcome Measures in Individuals With Hereditary or Sporadic Kidney Cancer

summary.text: The study emphasizes the importance of patient-reported outcome measures in understanding the impact of hereditary and sporadic kidney cancer on individuals' quality of life.
It highlights the need for comprehensive care that integrates clinical outcomes with patients' subjective experiences and perspectives.

The collaborative effort of a multidisciplinary team, including experts in VHL syndrome (Von Hippel-Lindau), underscores the complexity of managing these cancers and the value of coordinated patient care.
